title: Ticket #2420: preen finds stale ickpt files in spool directory --- why?
description:
Igor asks why preen found stale ickpt files in the spool directory: 

The condor_preen process has found the following
stale condor files on <glidein-1>:

  /opt/glidecondor/condor_local/schedd_glideins3/spool/3474/cluster233474.ickpt.subproc0 - Removed
  /opt/glidecondor/condor_local/schedd_glideins3/spool/3861/cluster233861.ickpt.subproc0 - Removed
  /opt/glidecondor/condor_local/schedd_glideins3/spool/3760/cluster233760.ickpt.subproc0 - Removed
  /opt/glidecondor/condor_local/schedd_glideins3/spool
<many more cases like the above --- 121 in total>

One thing that I find quite disturbing is the logic in condor_preen for deciding if a spooled file is still associated with a job that is in the queue. It queries the schedd to see if the job still exists. It does not distinguish between failure of the query and non-existence of the job!

The connection to the schedd is created with no timeout on the client side, but other things could go wrong: schedd times out, schedd dies in the middle of the query, network interruption.

Unfortunately for this theory, I see no evidence in the ScheddLog that any query errors happened when preen was running. I also confirmed that the cluster ids mentioned in the preen message do not appear in the job queue or in the history, which goes back two days.

Therefore, I think these deletions by condor_preen were legitimate garbage files. The question then is why these files got left behind. I don't yet have an explanation for that.
remarks:
2011-Sep-01 16:49:51 by danb:
Another incident of this problem happened. This time, I noticed that the job was removed forcibly: 

   LastHoldReason = "Globus error 131: the user proxy expired (job is still running)"
   HoldReason = "Globus error 121: the job state file doesn't exist"
   RemoveReason = "via condor_rm -forcex (by user gfactory)"

I experimented in 7.7.2 with submitting both vanilla and gt2 jobs and getting them into a state where they were removed (status appears as X). When in this state, preen still correctly sees that the file should not be removed. Then when I remove the job with condor_rm -forcex, the file is correctly removed. So I failed to reproduce the problem.

2012-Oct-31 15:46:00 by jfrey:
Igor found the source of this problem. When copy_to_spool is set to True or the job is standard universe, condor_submit spools the executable to the schedd as part of the queue-management transaction, before setting any of the job's attributes. If the transaction is aborted, the job is never submitted but the file isn't cleaned up by the schedd.

In Igor's case, the submission was aborted because the job's proxy was expired.

2012-Nov-02 16:47:46 by jfrey:
A possible solution is to call ClusterCleanup(), or some subset of it, in the schedd for each uncommitted cluster when aborting a transaction.
